item.title: Disconnect when I tried to equip blue mystic top?
item.dc:creator: @the_soul The Soul
item.description:
@the_soul wrote:

As xx qwertyuiop xx said, if you’re using i as the iterator you need to use it for all of them.

for(int i = 0; i < twoHanderz.length; i++) if(playerEquipment[playerWeapon] == twoHanderz[i])

Read full topic
item.source: Disconnect when I tried to equip blue mystic top?

item.title: Disconnect when I tried to equip blue mystic top?
item.dc:creator: @xx_qwertyuiop_xx xx qwertyuiop xx
item.description:
@xx_qwertyuiop_xx wrote:

Java is case-sensitive. You’re using one variable as an iterator and using another variable to access an index of the two-hander array.

Read full topic
item.source: Disconnect when I tried to equip blue mystic top?

item.title: Disconnect when I tried to equip blue mystic top?
item.dc:creator: @o.O_O.o o.O O.o
item.description:
@o.O_O.o wrote:

The only thing that comes to mind is when I bought a fighter torso and helm of Neitiznot from the shop, this occured. I tried to equip a blue mystic top, and disconnected. I got an error refering to:

public int[] twoHanderz = {7158,1319,6528}; public boolean is2Hander() { for(int I = 0; I < twoHanderz.length; I++) if(playerEquipment[playerWeapon] == twoHanderz[i]) return true; return false; }

What cause that to randomly be called, even? Blue mystic top isn’t a two hander… There was a fourth number in the array, 14000 something, but I got rid of that (I believe that didn’t fix the problem). What I did was lowercase int I, and it seemed to have fixed the problem. I just wonder if anyone knows why, or how, because I do not want this happening again.

Thanks.

Read full topic
item.source: Disconnect when I tried to equip blue mystic top?
